Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Situation2: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Story:
I glanced at my phone as I laced up my sneakers, ready for my evening gym session. As a police officer, staying fit isn’t just a personal goal—it’s a duty. My captain always says, “You can’t protect others if you can’t protect yourself.” I was about to head out when my younger brother barged into my room, his face flushed with frustration. He wanted to talk, to vent about a fight he’d had with our parents. I could see he needed me to listen, to be patient and understanding, to show him the respect he deserved as he tried to sort through his feelings.

But the clock was ticking. If I missed my gym slot, I’d be letting down my team and myself. Yet, if I brushed my brother off, I’d be failing him as a sibling, undermining the trust and respect we’d built. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other at the same time. I stood frozen in the doorway, torn between the badge on my chest and the bond of blood, my heart pounding with indecision.
